Curating the art

Source: vignettes/articles/curating-art.Rmd
curating-art.Rmd
library(arttools)

So now we are at the point where we’ve finished making art and we want to wrap it all up, create a nice “curated” version of the output, and prepare it for publication. At this point we might have something that looks like this:

#> /tmp/Rtmp8RS5w8/series-fake
#> ├── .gitignore
#> ├── .here
#> ├── LICENSE.md
#> ├── README.md
#> ├── build
#> ├── input
#> ├── output
#> │   ├── 01
#> │   │   ├── art-system_01_0001.png
#> │   │   ├── art-system_01_0002.png
#> │   │   ├── art-system_01_0003.png
#> │   │   ├── art-system_01_0004.png
#> │   │   └── art-system_01_0005.png
#> │   └── 02
#> │       ├── art-system_02_0001.png
#> │       ├── art-system_02_0002.png
#> │       ├── art-system_02_0003.png
#> │       ├── art-system_02_0004.png
#> │       └── art-system_02_0005.png
#> ├── series-fake
#> └── source
#>     ├── art-system_01.R
#>     ├── art-system_02.R
#>     └── common.R

Obviously, in real life you probably have more versions of the system and more outputs from each system, but this will suffice to illustrate how the process works.

Regarding curation

Curation is mostly a manual process, and for good reason. Generative art systems don’t always create images that I find pleasing, and I see no reason to publish the bad ones. There’s an aesthetic I want to preserve whenever I publish a generative art series, and I have no qualms at all about choosing the images that I like (and ignoring the ones I don’t) when I do so. At a pretty deep level, I’m not interested in “long form” generative art, where the artist publishes the system and doesn’t curate the output. Art is a human process, even generative art, and – in my opinion – it becomes very boring when you remove the curatorial aspect. Every time I’ve tried to design a “long form” system, I’ve found myself creating boring art.

I’m going to expand on that point a little, because I suspect it’s non-obvious. Long form generative art has a tendency to become boring because it changes your incentive as an artist. When you create a “long form” system, you end up trying to ensure that every output is pleasing. A long form system that produces magnificent art 5% of the time but horrible art 95% of the time is unworkable. As a consequence, the long form generative artist is incentivised to modify the system in a way that “raises the floor”. Long form generative art is fundamentally about creating systems where “the worst output is sort of pretty and doesn’t suck”. When you make this your goal, you get conservative. You don’t want your systems to try out crazy things, because – let’s be honest – most crazy things are batshit insane and hideous. And so, to ensure that the worse-case art isn’t awful, you end up restricting your systems so that they have very little range.

The outputs become… consistently pleasant, but never amazing.

That’s fine if that’s your thing, but I prefer to design systems that produce magnificent pieces occasionally, even if that means that the systems produce a lot of utter garbage as well.

Given that ethos, arttools assumes that you’re going to choose a small subset of the images in the output folder and move them into the series-fake folder (or whatever it actually is for your system). The only images that you will want to publish later on are the curated images in series-fake.

Creating the curated version

Okay, let’s set the polemics aside and assume you’ve made some choices about which images you want to publish. In practice, what that means is that chosen some images that you like and you’ve copied them to the series-fake folder (or whatever it happens to be called). So now you have something like this:

#> /tmp/Rtmp8RS5w8/series-fake
#> ├── .gitignore
#> ├── .here
#> ├── LICENSE.md
#> ├── README.md
#> ├── build
#> ├── input
#> ├── output
#> │   ├── 01
#> │   │   ├── art-system_01_0001.png
#> │   │   ├── art-system_01_0002.png
#> │   │   ├── art-system_01_0003.png
#> │   │   ├── art-system_01_0004.png
#> │   │   └── art-system_01_0005.png
#> │   └── 02
#> │       ├── art-system_02_0001.png
#> │       ├── art-system_02_0002.png
#> │       ├── art-system_02_0003.png
#> │       ├── art-system_02_0004.png
#> │       └── art-system_02_0005.png
#> ├── series-fake
#> │   └── image
#> │       ├── art-system_01_0002.png
#> │       ├── art-system_01_0003.png
#> │       ├── art-system_02_0003.png
#> │       └── art-system_02_0005.png
#> └── source
#>     ├── art-system_01.R
#>     ├── art-system_02.R
#>     └── common.R

Notice that the “curated” version in series-fake places the images in an image folder. The reason for that is that – usually – the images you create with your generative art system are high resolution, so you’re going to want to have low-res versions of the same images that you can use as “thumbnail” previews on your generative art website.

Creating thumbnail images

The arttools package supplies a function to create all your thumbnails for you, boringly entitled create_resized_images().

create_resized_images(
  series = "series-fake",
  images_from = "series-fake/image",
  images_to = "series-fake/preview",
  pixels_wide = 500,
  pixels_high = 500,
  origin = tempdir()
)
#> ✔ /tmp/Rtmp8RS5w8/series-fake/series-fake/preview/art-system_01_0002.png created
#> ✔ /tmp/Rtmp8RS5w8/series-fake/series-fake/preview/art-system_01_0003.png created
#> ✔ /tmp/Rtmp8RS5w8/series-fake/series-fake/preview/art-system_02_0003.png created
#> ✔ /tmp/Rtmp8RS5w8/series-fake/series-fake/preview/art-system_02_0005.png created

So now we have:

#> /tmp/Rtmp8RS5w8/series-fake
#> ├── .gitignore
#> ├── .here
#> ├── LICENSE.md
#> ├── README.md
#> ├── build
#> ├── input
#> ├── output
#> │   ├── 01
#> │   │   ├── art-system_01_0001.png
#> │   │   ├── art-system_01_0002.png
#> │   │   ├── art-system_01_0003.png
#> │   │   ├── art-system_01_0004.png
#> │   │   └── art-system_01_0005.png
#> │   └── 02
#> │       ├── art-system_02_0001.png
#> │       ├── art-system_02_0002.png
#> │       ├── art-system_02_0003.png
#> │       ├── art-system_02_0004.png
#> │       └── art-system_02_0005.png
#> ├── series-fake
#> │   ├── image
#> │   │   ├── art-system_01_0002.png
#> │   │   ├── art-system_01_0003.png
#> │   │   ├── art-system_02_0003.png
#> │   │   └── art-system_02_0005.png
#> │   └── preview
#> │       ├── art-system_01_0002.png
#> │       ├── art-system_01_0003.png
#> │       ├── art-system_02_0003.png
#> │       └── art-system_02_0005.png
#> └── source
#>     ├── art-system_01.R
#>     ├── art-system_02.R
#>     └── common.R

The repository now contains the “full resolution” images in the series-fake/image folder, and lower resolution versions of the same images in the series-fake/preview folder. Or, to narrow things down to the folder that we’re planning to publish, this is where we’re at:

#> /tmp/Rtmp8RS5w8/series-fake/series-fake
#> ├── image
#> │   ├── art-system_01_0002.png
#> │   ├── art-system_01_0003.png
#> │   ├── art-system_02_0003.png
#> │   └── art-system_02_0005.png
#> └── preview
#>     ├── art-system_01_0002.png
#>     ├── art-system_01_0003.png
#>     ├── art-system_02_0003.png
#>     └── art-system_02_0005.png

Creating manifest files

The series-fake folder (… contained within the series-fake repository, which should kinda be a hint that it’s going to be moved later!) isn’t really intended to stay in the repository forever. Rather, it’s something that we’re going to publish to the web eventually. It’s going to live in the cloud storage bucket listed in bucket_remote_path(). However, when we move it online, we’re going to need a manifest file that lists all the files contained in the series-fake bucket. We need this so that the website that we’re going to build later on will have an easy way to discover all the images in our curated set.

Yes, this is getting exhausting. Fortunately, the arttools package has a function called manifest_write() that will create exactly the file we need:

# yes, this is something that I will need to tidy later:
# I wrote manifest_write() thinking it would be called 
# with respect to the local bucket path not the local 
# repo path, and its not robust if you do it the other 
# way around. So this very ugly note is here to remind
# me that this part of the package/workflow needs to be
# reconsidered
blah <- file.path(tempdir(), "series-fake")

manifest_write("series-fake", origin = blah, destination = blah)

And now we have a manifest.csv file:

#> /tmp/Rtmp8RS5w8/series-fake/series-fake
#> ├── image
#> │   ├── art-system_01_0002.png
#> │   ├── art-system_01_0003.png
#> │   ├── art-system_02_0003.png
#> │   └── art-system_02_0005.png
#> ├── manifest.csv
#> └── preview
#>     ├── art-system_01_0002.png
#>     ├── art-system_01_0003.png
#>     ├── art-system_02_0003.png
#>     └── art-system_02_0005.png

Here’s what it looks like:

manifest_read("series-fake", origin = blah)
#> # A tibble: 8 × 12
#>   series_name series_date path          folder file_name file_format system_name
#>   <chr>       <date>      <chr>         <chr>  <chr>     <chr>       <chr>      
#> 1 series-fake 2023-07-27  image/art-sy… image  art-syst… png         art-system 
#> 2 series-fake 2023-07-27  preview/art-… previ… art-syst… png         art-system 
#> 3 series-fake 2023-07-27  image/art-sy… image  art-syst… png         art-system 
#> 4 series-fake 2023-07-27  preview/art-… previ… art-syst… png         art-system 
#> 5 series-fake 2023-07-27  image/art-sy… image  art-syst… png         art-system 
#> 6 series-fake 2023-07-27  preview/art-… previ… art-syst… png         art-system 
#> 7 series-fake 2023-07-27  image/art-sy… image  art-syst… png         art-system 
#> 8 series-fake 2023-07-27  preview/art-… previ… art-syst… png         art-system 
#> # ℹ 5 more variables: system_version <chr>, image_id <chr>,
#> #   image_short_title <chr>, image_long_title <chr>, manifest_version <int>

At this point we have a complete folder that we can drop straight into the remote bucket and publish.
